Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism.

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them.

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

text:
If you choose not to be an idiot who takes things at face value, you'll soon realize Bernie Sanders is one of the most damaging and destructive con artists and deceivers in the whole world right now. 

'But he calls Netanyahu a war criminal', you'd say in defense of this pseudo-radical for the bourgeois. 'So what?' I'll write you back. What does this mean if it's not backed up by action? What does it do except bolster the system? 

Would you be a member of a lynching club but just not while they were doing the actual lynching? Because this is all Sanders is: a valve to lock fantasy radicals into the system that guarantees the continuation of the oppression. 

Sanders claims to know Netanyahu is a war criminal, but he continues to sit and be part of the body that provides the moral and financial support required for committing said war crimes, all while pretending he's against it and helping the system portray itself as a democracy.  

In doing so, he perpetuates the poisonous lie that one must never break rank with the party and the establishment, no matter what they do. 

This is more destructive for the possibility of change than any other political position. This is more deadly for victims of US imperialism than the stupidest Brian Mast. 

This is what establishment people cast for a Bernie Sanders role do: they strengthen the establishments and create a false impression by which only the establishment is a possible choice.  

And by pretending to be aware a great crime is being committed while staying on the board that actually does it, by power of their action, or inaction, they are really saying: this isn't so bad after all. 

And this is all late-stage performative colonial capitalist madhouse. People know all this intuitively, they just let their minds get foggy intentionally not to face the music. 

If you believe murdering children is wrong, you cut all ties with the people who do it, period. And if you do not cut ties with them, you don't think murdering children is wrong.  
   
Israel and the US establishments are murdering children. Make your fucking choice. It is not difficult

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."

Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism. 

The video, which gained global attention, was filmed by his mother, Yarraka Bayles, on February 19, 2020. It shows Quaden in a highly distressed state, crying uncontrollably in the back of a car after a day at school where he was bullied.

So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

text:
Long post warning ğŸš¨ 

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s. 

Then it all started to change. Trump in 2016 flipped everything on its head. Suddenly republicans were much less hawkish, ignoring foreign wars. and the liberals lost their mind with TDS. So everything then became a reaction to trump. 

Then covid hit and things really got weird.

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."

Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism. 

The video, which gained global attention, was filmed by his mother, Yarraka Bayles, on February 19, 2020. It shows Quaden in a highly distressed state, crying uncontrollably in the back of a car after a day at school where he was bullied. 

The emotional intensity of the video is evident as Quaden expresses a desire to harm himself, saying, â€œI wish I could stab myself in the heartâ€ and â€œGive me a knife, I want to k*ll myselfâ€â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.

This video resonated with millions around the world, highlighting the severe impact of bullying on young individuals, particularly those with physical differences.

To make matters even worse, cyber bullies attacked the family and made false claims about Quaden's age. 

This ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ is the original video. It's truly heartbreaking ğŸ˜ª

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s. 

Then it all started to change. Trump in 2016 flipped everything on its head. Suddenly republicans were much less hawkish, ignoring foreign wars. and the liberals lost their mind with TDS. So everything then became a reaction to trump. 

Then covid hit and things really got weird. 

Liberals started pushing for even greater state control. Forced closures of businesses, executive orders, vaccine mandates, clamping down on constitutional rights. 

And they also started cheering US military action abroad in the Ukraine. Obama started this with his love for drone warfare. Now we see the left cheering the political prosecution of their political opponents. Grim.

text:
10. Club Friday Season 16: Love Bully (2024)

Episodes: 4
Airs: Jun 7, 2024 - Jun 28, 2024
Airs On: Friday
Original Network: One 31

Main Cast: Charlotte Austin , Engfa Waraha

Plot
In the era of social media, everyone can freely express their opinions about others. They can use harsh words without much consideration, not thinking about the consequences or verifying the truth.

In a relationship between two women, one becomes overly concerned with the opinions of others, making her vulnerable to someone she doesn't know who ends up hurting her. The second woman has never cared much, firmly believing in the adage "to each their own." However, at times, she can be remarkably oblivious to the feelings of those around her.

Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism.

text:
Long post warning ğŸš¨ 

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s. 

Then it all started to change. Trump in 2016 flipped everything on its head. Suddenly republicans were much less hawkish, ignoring foreign wars. and the liberals lost their mind with TDS. So everything then became a reaction to trump.

Glad to see Quaden is doing well after everything the poor kid endured from bullies...at school & online!

More context:
Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism. 

The video, which gained global attention, was filmed by his mother, Yarraka Bayles, on February 19, 2020. It shows Quaden in a highly distressed state, crying uncontrollably in the back of a car after a day at school where he was bullied. 

The emotional intensity of the video is evident as Quaden expresses a desire to harm himself, saying, â€œI wish I could stab myself in the heartâ€ and â€œGive me a knife, I want to k*ll myselfâ€â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.

This video resonated with millions around the world, highlighting the severe impact of bullying on young individuals, particularly those with physical differences.

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird. 

Liberals started pushing for even greater state control. Forced closures of businesses, executive orders, vaccine mandates, clamping down on constitutional rights. 

And they also started cheering US military action abroad in the Ukraine. Obama started this with his love for drone warfare. Now we see the left cheering the political prosecution of their political opponents. Grim.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Airs On: Friday
Original Network: One 31

Main Cast: Charlotte Austin , Engfa Waraha

Plot
In the era of social media, everyone can freely express their opinions about others. They can use harsh words without much consideration, not thinking about the consequences or verifying the truth.

In a relationship between two women, one becomes overly concerned with the opinions of others, making her vulnerable to someone she doesn't know who ends up hurting her. The second woman has never cared much, firmly believing in the adage "to each their own." However, at times, she can be remarkably oblivious to the feelings of those around her.

With their love in the spotlight, eyes across the nation scrutinise their every move, passing judgement on ever action.

Episodes: 4
Airs: Jun 7, 2024 - Jun 28, 2024
Airs On: Friday
Original Network: One 31

Main Cast: Charlotte Austin , Engfa Waraha

Plot
In the era of social media, everyone can freely express their opinions about others. They can use harsh words without much consideration, not thinking about the consequences or verifying the truth.

In a relationship between two women, one becomes overly concerned with the opinions of others, making her vulnerable to someone she doesn't know who ends up hurting her. The second woman has never cared much, firmly believing in the adage "to each their own." However, at times, she can be remarkably oblivious to the feelings of those around her.

With their love in the spotlight, eyes across the nation scrutinise their every move, passing judgement on ever action.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird. 

Liberals started pushing for even greater state control. Forced closures of businesses, executive orders, vaccine mandates, clamping down on constitutional rights.

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

Long post warning ğŸš¨ 

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s. 

Then it all started to change. Trump in 2016 flipped everything on its head. Suddenly republicans were much less hawkish, ignoring foreign wars. and the liberals lost their mind with TDS. So everything then became a reaction to trump. 

Then covid hit and things really got weird. 

Liberals started pushing for even greater state control. Forced closures of businesses, executive orders, vaccine mandates, clamping down on constitutional rights. 

And they also started cheering US military action abroad in the Ukraine. Obama started this with his love for drone warfare. Now we see the left cheering the political prosecution of their political opponents. Grim. 

So now, all the sudden, the anti-establishment left of the last 60 years has swung hard to become the people theyâ€™ve fought against. 

And thereâ€™s nothing less punk rock than fighting for the establishment.

So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them.

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

Quaden Bayles, an Australian indigenous boy, became the focus of a viral video in 2020. Quaden was born with achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism. 

The video, which gained global attention, was filmed by his mother, Yarraka Bayles, on February 19, 2020. It shows Quaden in a highly distressed state, crying uncontrollably in the back of a car after a day at school where he was bullied. 

The emotional intensity of the video is evident as Quaden expresses a desire to harm himself, saying, â€œI wish I could stab myself in the heartâ€ and â€œGive me a knife, I want to k*ll myselfâ€â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹.

This video resonated with millions around the world, highlighting the severe impact of bullying on young individuals, particularly those with physical differences.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

Then covid hit and things really got weird.

text:
So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. At that time I felt obliged to do that, and to try and engage, because we were ostensibly â€˜on the same side.â€™ That was a mistake, and it caused me harm. 

I have since decided I am not obliged to be anybodyâ€™s punching bag. And I now advise anyone else who ends up in a similar situation the same. If you sit around in the corner of peopleâ€™s mentions talking shit about them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you impugn their motives or character donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them. 

There is still a lot of work to be done. It will go much better if it can be done with as much good will and light as possible.

So just to be clear. In the autumn of 2022 I ended up in an eight week pile on in which I spent a long time trying to reason with people who were not interested in any good faith engagement and whose behaviour towards me was at best hostile and at worst extremely abusive. If you lie about them or smear them donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. If you like tweets doing these things donâ€™t be surprised if they block you. 

Nobody is obliged to be anybody elseâ€™s punching bag and they have every right to protect themselves as they see fit in order to be able to carry on their work and lives without absorbing whatever spite or rage you think you should be able to chuck at them.

I think Iâ€™ve figured out why Iâ€™m so turned off with the current left: they have become the establishment. 

Growing up the Republican Party, with its oppressive brand of moral conservatism, felt like the owners of the â€œestablishment.â€

The hippies and the left were a reaction to that. Free love, rock and roll, anti-war, anti-establishment.  That was followed by punk rock culture â€” liberals continued to be the standard bearers of the antiestablishment. 

Even into the 90s/2000s, you had anti-war liberals pushing back against the Falwell moral majority and protesting the Iraq war (that was me ğŸ‘‹).  Then the pushback to the disastrous neocon political movement of the post-9/11 2000s.

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."

text:
High Court and Court of Appeal Ruling Ignored as Senior DCI Officers Harass Landowner 

In 2010, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji, and Ashvin Ramji purchased a parcel of land from the National Social Security Fund (NSSF).

This prime real estate situated along Mombasa Road Next to the Mombasa Cement factory was a major investment but what began as a promising acquisition soon spiraled into a bitter legal battle marked by fraud, goon invasion, and allegations of corruption within our law enforcement system.

The Ramji family's ordeal started innocuously enough.

They acquired the land legally, receiving the title deed from NSSF.

But as fate would have it, Mombasa Cement Limited, a powerful entity with deep connections, had its sights set on the same land.

In a brazen move, Mombasa Cement deposited money into the NSSF account without any formal agreement or authorization, following which they orchestrated an illegal eviction of the Ramjis using hired goons who not only evicted them but also demolished parts of the boundary wall to amalgamate the property with their own factory premises.

The Ramjis, now dispossessed of their land, sought justice in the High Court at Milimani.

Justice Kossy Bor presided over the case, which seemed straightforward enough given the clear legal ownership documents the Ramjis held but in a surprising turn of events, Justice Bor ruled in favor of Mombasa Cement, validating the company's counterclaims of fraud and improper acquisition against the Ramjis.

The ruling shocked many and was perceived as a glaring miscarriage of justice.

Undeterred, the Ramjis appealed to the Court of Appeal and their persistence paid off.

In Civil Appeal No. 590 of 2019, the appellate judges â€“ Justices Musinga, Ngenye, and Omondi â€“ delivered a scathing critique of the lower court's judgment.

They meticulously dismantled the arguments presented by Mombasa Cement and acknowledged the validity of the Ramjis' title.

The Court of Appeal ordered that the land be restored to the Ramjis and Mombasa Cement evicted.

By March 2024, the property was rightfully back in the hands of its owners which marked a legal victory for the family.

But the victory was short-lived.

Mombasa Cement (leveraging its connections within the corridors of power) launched a retaliatory campaign.

Using its influence, particularly its involvement in constructing police station walls in Mombasa and Nairobi, Mombasa Cement enlisted the help of high-ranking officers within the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and reportedly hatched a plan to reverse the Court of Appeal's decision.

The strategy was to use their authority to harass and intimidate the Ramji family in an attempt to coerce them into relinquishing their land once more.

The summonses came swiftly.

Bharat, Harish, and Ashvin Ramji were repeatedly called in for questioning by the DCI.

Under relentless pressure, they turned to the judicial system for protection.

Kiambu High Court became their refuge.

On 24th April 2024, Bharat Ramji, Harish Ramji and Ashvin Ramji obtained crucial judicial review orders from the Kiambu High Court which were signed by Hon. Lady Justice Dorah Chepkwony. 

These orders were issued to restrain the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Inspector General of Police from arresting or harassing the Ramji family. 

The application was certified as urgent.

Court granted leave to the Ramjis to file a substantive judicial review application which allowed them to formally challenge the actions of the DCI and the Inspector General of Police.

The leave granted operated as a stay, meaning that any actions by the DCI or the Inspector General of Police to arrest or harass the Ramjis were temporarily halted pending the hearing and determination of the substantive judicial review 

The matter was set for mention on 20th June 2024 to confirm compliance with the court orders and to ensure that the judicial process was being followed correctly.

DCI and Inspector General of Police were given seven days upon service of the court orders to file their response to the judicial review application.

Despite having been served with orders restraining the arrest via Kiambu High Court Judicial Review Case No. HCJR/E010/2024, Wilhelm K. Kimutai (emboldened by his connections and a misplaced sense of invincibility) continued his campaign of harassment, ignoring the High Court's orders and further complicating the Ramji family's efforts to reclaim their property.

In their detailed judgment, the Court of Appeal judges found substantial flaws in the initial trial court's handling of the case.

They pointed out several key misdirections.

The appellate court noted that the trial judge had disregarded crucial evidence regarding the assignment of the suit property from Golden Terrace to the Ramjis.

"The learned judge failed to appreciate and give effect to the provisions of section 23 (1) of the Registration of Titles Act," the Court of Appeal stated.

The Court of Appeal also underscored the indefensibility of the Ramjis' title, stating, "There was no dispute that they were the registered proprietors of the suit property." The judges criticized the trial court for not recognizing this legal fact.

Addressing the clerical error in the transfer documents, the Court of Appeal clarified, "It is obvious that there was a clerical error in the preparation of the transfer document in making reference to LR No. 11895/48 when the subject matter in the entire transfer was LR No. 11895/50."
